definitions: relating to or supporting the political movement for establishing and developing a Jewish nation in Israel
advocating for or supporting the rights and interests of Jewish people to self-determination in their homeland
examples: The zionist movement gained momentum after World War Two
Several zionist organizations worked to establish settlements
His zionist beliefs shaped his political views throughout life
The zionist conference brought together leaders from many nations

definitions: relating to or characteristic of the ancient Persian religion founded by Zoroaster based on worship of Ahura Mazda
examples: The zoroastrian temple contained sacred fire that burned continuously
Ancient zoroastrian texts reveal complex theological concepts

definitions: left empty or deserted by people who previously occupied or used it
completely given up or discontinued with no intention of resuming
showing complete lack of inhibition or restraint in behavior or manner
examples: The abandoned building stood dark against the evening sky
Children played in the abandoned lot behind the school
She pursued her abandoned dreams after years of delay
The abandoned project left investors with significant losses
He danced with abandoned joy at the celebration
Her abandoned laughter filled the entire room

definitions: shortened by omitting parts while retaining the essential elements or meaning
reduced in duration or extent from what was originally planned or expected
examples: The abbreviated version contained only the main points
She used abbreviated notes during her presentation
The storm caused an abbreviated baseball season this year
His abbreviated visit disappointed his waiting family

definitions: relating to or located in the abdomen, the part of the body containing digestive organs
examples: The patient complained of severe abdominal pain yesterday
Regular abdominal exercises strengthen your core muscles effectively

definitions: in the act of taking someone away by force or deception, typically for criminal purposes
examples: The abducting vehicle sped away from the scene
Police identified the abducting group through surveillance footage

definitions: departing from an accepted standard, norm, or typical pattern of behavior or occurrence
straying from the right, normal, or usual course in a moral or ethical sense
examples: The scientist studied aberrant cell growth in cancer patients
His aberrant behavior at work concerned his colleagues
Society must address aberrant conduct that harms vulnerable populations
The aberrant decision violated established ethical principles

definitions: inspiring intense disgust, hatred, or loathing; utterly repugnant and morally reprehensible
examples: The abhorrent crime shocked the entire community deeply
She found his racist views absolutely abhorrent

definitions: continuing without change; enduring for a long time or permanently
respecting and obeying laws, rules, or agreements consistently
examples: She maintained an abiding love for classical music
His abiding interest in astronomy began in childhood
The abiding citizens respected all local regulations carefully
As abiding members, they followed club rules strictly

definitions: extremely bad, unpleasant, or degrading; of the most miserable kind possible
completely without pride or dignity; showing utter submission or hopelessness
examples: They lived in abject poverty for many difficult years
The refugees faced abject conditions in the camp
His abject apology revealed complete loss of dignity
She made an abject surrender to their demands

definitions: burning fiercely with flames visible and spreading actively
very brightly lit up or illuminated with lights or colors
filled with or showing strong emotion, excitement, or passionate feeling
examples: The building was ablaze before firefighters arrived
The forest stood ablaze during the wildfire
The city was ablaze with holiday lights
The sunset left the sky ablaze with color
Her eyes were ablaze with righteous anger
The crowd was ablaze with excitement

definitions: having the power, skill, means, or opportunity to do something
having considerable skill, proficiency, or intelligence; competent and talented
examples: She was able to solve the complex problem
The child is able to read at grade level
The able lawyer won several difficult cases
They hired able workers for the project

definitions: deviating from what is normal, usual, or expected in general circumstances
differing from the typical structure or function in medical or biological terms
examples: The abnormal weather patterns concerned climate scientists
His abnormal behavior at dinner surprised everyone
The doctor found abnormal cells during the examination
Blood tests revealed abnormal liver function values

definitions: causing moral revulsion; extremely offensive and deserving strong condemnation
extremely unpleasant, disagreeable, or of very poor quality
examples: The dictator committed abominable crimes against humanity
Their abominable treatment of prisoners violated human rights
The weather was abominable throughout our vacation
The restaurant served abominable food last night

definitions: inhabiting or existing in a land from the earliest times or before colonization; indigenous
examples: The museum displayed aboriginal art from various cultures
They studied aboriginal languages of the Pacific islands

definitions: failing to produce the intended result; unsuccessful or fruitless in outcome
causing or relating to the termination of pregnancy or development
examples: Their abortive attempt to climb the mountain ended quickly
The abortive rebellion lasted only three days
The medication had potential abortive effects on pregnancy
Certain infections can cause abortive development in plants

definitions: existing, occurring, or operating above the surface of the ground
examples: The aboveground pool was easier to maintain
Aboveground storage tanks require regular inspection

definitions: capable of polishing or cleaning by rubbing or grinding; having a rough surface
showing little concern for others' feelings; harsh and unfriendly in manner
examples: The abrasive cleaner removed stubborn stains effectively
Use abrasive paper to smooth the wood surface
His abrasive personality made collaboration difficult
Her abrasive comments offended several team members

definitions: side by side and facing the same way, typically in movement
up to date with the latest news, ideas, or developments
examples: The soldiers marched four abreast down the street
Two cars cannot travel abreast on this narrow road
She keeps abreast of technological developments
Stay abreast of changes in your industry

definitions: shortened in length while preserving the essential content and overall meaning
examples: The abridged dictionary fits easily in your backpack
Students often prefer abridged versions of classic novels

definitions: sudden and unexpected, often in an unpleasant way; happening without warning
brief to the point of rudeness; curt and unfriendly in speech or manner
examples: The car made an abrupt stop at the intersection
His abrupt departure surprised everyone at the meeting
She gave an abrupt reply and walked away
His abrupt manner offended the new clients

definitions: not present in a place, at an occasion, or as part of something
showing that one's mind is not focused on the immediate surroundings or situation
examples: Three students were absent from class today
The necessary equipment was absent from the laboratory
She had an absent expression during the lecture
His absent manner suggested deep preoccupation

definitions: complete and total, with no qualification, restriction, or limitation
not qualified or diminished in any way; used for emphasis
viewed or existing independently and not in relation to other things
examples: The court demands absolute silence during proceedings
She has absolute control over company decisions
That statement is absolute nonsense
He spoke with absolute certainty about the matter
They discussed absolute values in mathematics class
Scientists seek absolute truth through rigorous experimentation

definitions: believing in or supporting a system of government with unlimited power, or adherence to absolute principles
examples: His absolutist views on morality allowed no exceptions
The absolutist regime crushed all political opposition

definitions: formally released from guilt, obligation, or punishment; declared free from blame or responsibility
examples: The court absolved him of all criminal charges
She felt absolved after confessing her mistakes

definitions: deeply interested and giving complete attention to something
having been taken in or soaked up completely by something else
examples: She was absorbed in reading her favorite novel
The children were absorbed by the magic show
The sponge absorbed all the spilled water quickly
The company was absorbed by a larger corporation

definitions: able to soak up liquid or moisture easily through pores or interstices
examples: These absorbent towels dry dishes quickly and efficiently
The absorbent material prevented spills from spreading

definitions: extremely interesting and holding one's complete attention for extended periods
examples: The detective novel was thoroughly absorbing from start to finish
She found the documentary absorbing and educational

definitions: existing in thought or as an idea but not having physical or concrete existence
dealing with ideas rather than events or physical objects
presented in a condensed form summarizing the essential points
examples: Mathematics deals with abstract concepts like infinity
The philosopher discussed abstract notions of justice
Abstract art doesn't represent recognizable objects
Her abstract thinking impressed the professors
Read the abstract before the full research paper
The abstract provides a brief overview

definitions: showing that one's thoughts are elsewhere; preoccupied and not paying attention to surroundings
examples: He had an abstracted air while pondering the problem
Her abstracted gaze suggested deep contemplation

definitions: wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate to the point of being laughable
inconsistent with reason or logic; ridiculously incongruous or unreasonable
examples: The price they asked was absolutely absurd
It's absurd to think we can finish today
The absurd situation made everyone laugh nervously
His absurd costume drew stares at the formal event

definitions: existing or available in large quantities; more than sufficient; plentiful
having plenty of something; well supplied with resources or materials
examples: The garden produced abundant vegetables this season
Abundant rainfall helped crops grow successfully
The region is abundant in natural resources
She felt abundant joy at the reunion

definitions: treated with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly
used wrongly or improperly; taken advantage of
examples: The abused children received counseling and support
Abused animals were rescued from the facility
The abused privilege was revoked by management
His abused trust could never be restored

definitions: extremely offensive and insulting in language or behavior
engaging in or characterized by physical or psychological maltreatment
examples: His abusive language shocked everyone present
The abusive comments were removed from the forum
She escaped from an abusive relationship last year
The abusive parent lost custody rights

definitions: extremely bad; appalling to a degree that causes dismay or disgust
extremely deep or seemingly bottomless like an abyss
examples: The team's abysmal performance disappointed their fans
Test scores were abysmal across the district
The submarine explored abysmal ocean depths
They stared into the abysmal chasm below

definitions: relating to or denoting the depths of the ocean, especially below 2000 meters
examples: Scientists discovered new abyssal species near thermal vents
The abyssal plain covers vast ocean floor areas

definitions: relating to education and scholarship, especially at college or university level
concerned with scholarly pursuits rather than practical or vocational skills
not of practical relevance; of only theoretical interest
examples: She achieved academic excellence throughout her studies
The academic year begins in September
His academic approach emphasized theory over practice
The journal publishes academic research papers
The point became academic when funding was withdrawn
Whether he would have succeeded is now academic

definitions: increased in speed, rate, or velocity of movement or action
happening or developing more quickly than usual or expected
examples: The car's accelerated pace alarmed other drivers
Scientists observed accelerated particle movement
The accelerated program allows early graduation
Climate change shows accelerated warming patterns

definitions: spoken with a distinctive pronunciation indicating regional or foreign origin
given special emphasis or stress; marked by a distinctive feature
examples: Her accented English revealed her French origins
The accented speech charmed his audience
The accented syllables determine the rhythm
She wore an accented scarf with her outfit

definitions: able to be agreed to, approved of, or allowed to happen
satisfactory or adequate though not exceptionally good
examples: Your proposal is acceptable to the committee
This behavior is not acceptable in class
The food was acceptable but not memorable
His performance was barely acceptable

definitions: generally approved or recognized as normal, right, or reasonable
believed or recognized as valid or correct
examples: This is the accepted way to format citations
The accepted practice has been followed for decades
Her theory became accepted after extensive testing
The accepted facts support our conclusion

definitions: willing to allow or accept something or someone; receptive
willing to accept people and situations as they are; tolerant
examples: She was accepting of constructive criticism
The accepting audience embraced the new ideas
The community was accepting of different lifestyles
His accepting nature made him easy to befriend

definitions: able to be reached, entered, or used by people, including those with disabilities
easily understood or appreciated; not overly complex or technical
friendly and easy to talk to; approachable
examples: The building is fully accessible to wheelchair users
The files are accessible through the network
She writes accessible books about complex science
The museum made art accessible to everyone
The professor was accessible to all students
Despite fame, she remained accessible to fans

definitions: contributing to or aiding an activity or process in a minor way; supplementary
helping someone commit a crime without directly participating in it
examples: The accessory muscles assist with breathing
These are accessory features, not essential ones
He was charged as an accessory to the robbery
Being an accessory after the fact is illegal

definitions: happening by chance or without intention; not deliberate or planned
examples: The discovery was completely accidental but groundbreaking
An accidental meeting changed their lives forever

definitions: eager to help or please others; obliging and willing to fit in with someone's wishes
examples: The accommodating staff made our stay pleasant
She was very accommodating about schedule changes

definitions: occurring, appearing, or done in conjunction with something or someone else
examples: The meal was accompanied by excellent wine
Children must be accompanied by an adult

definitions: provided, occurring, or done at the same time as something else; going along with
examples: Read the accompanying instructions before assembly
The accompanying symptoms include fever and fatigue

definitions: highly skilled or expert in a particular activity; having achieved distinction
examples: She's an accomplished pianist who performs internationally
The accomplished chef opened her third restaurant

definitions: in a manner conforming with or agreeing to something specified
examples: Everything went according to our original plan
Proceed according to the established guidelines
